did.unittitle: Rolland and Lottie Welch Papers
did.abstract: The work of medical missionary Rolland Welch and his wife Lottie in Hunan, China from 1917 to 1923 is documented by letters, writings, photographs, lantern slides, printed material, and memorabilia.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open to qualified researchers.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Rolland and Lottie Welch Papers (RG 224), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Rolland Aretus Welch was born on November 16, 1884 in Shepherd, Michigan, the son of Russell and Isabella Asenath Welch. He attended public schools and graduated in 1908 from Spring Arbor Seminary, an academy founded by leaders of the Free Methodist Church. Rolland then trained for one year at the American Missionary Medical College before beginning work at the Battle Creek Sanitarium in Michigan. Raised in a religious family, Rolland became a professing Christian at age ten, Sunday School Superintendent by age fourteen, and a licensed preacher by age seventeen.

Lottie Belle McClain was born April 23, 1885 in Centerville, Michigan, the daughter of Reuben and Clementine Carr McClain. Her mother died when she was a toddler so her father's brother and wife (William McClain) raised her. Her aunt died when she was thirteen years old and she lived with her cousin before going to work in the paper mills in Three Rivers, Michigan. In order to be closer to work, she found a room with Will and Mary Bridgman, who provided a family relationship for her in future years. Lottie moved to Battle Creek, Michigan in 1902. She became a Christian in 1904 and united with the Free Methodist Church in 1904. She began nurses training a the Battle Creek Sanitarium in 1907, where she met Rolland Welch.

Rolland and Lottie married on August 19, 1909. The couple went to Washington, Kansas where Rolland served as a minister for one year. They returned to Battle Creek in August 1910. Their first child, Rolland William, was born on September 9, 1912 but lived for only ten days, due to injuries related to birth trauma. Their daughter, Mabel, was born on May 31, 1914. Rolland resumed his medical training at the University of Illinois, into which the American Missionary Medical College had merged, and received his M.D. in 1915. Rolland worked as a physician and surgeon at the Battle Creek Sanitarium until April, 1917, when he was appointed as a medical missionary under the United Evangelical Mission. The United Evangelical Church was created in 1891 when some members of the Evangelical Association, also known as the Albright Brethren, left to form the new church. In 1922 the two groups reunited in Detroit and renamed themselves "The Evangelical Church."

Lottie completed the "First Standard Teacher Training Course" given by the Teacher Training Board of the Free Methodist Church in May 1917 but required additional education in order to join the United Evangelical Mission in China. After Rolland sailed for China, Lottie and Mabel remained in Greenville, Illinois where she attend the Greenville College Preparatory School, graduating in June 1918. Lottie and Mabel sailed for China in September, 1918. They remained in Nanking for a few months for language study before joining Rolland because women and children were not allowed to go Yuhsien at that time, due to war conditions. During the summer months Lottie and Mabel lived at the missionary resort in Kuling. Rolland was Superintendent of Emma Dubs Memorial Hospital in Yuhsien, Hunan province until 1923. The Emma Dubs Memorial Hospital was built in 1919-1920 under the direction of Rev. C.C. Talbott and Dr. Rolland Welch, who had earlier opened a dispensary in Yuhsien.

Rolland suffered from acute ill health in late 1922 and early 1923 and the Welches returned to the U.S. for furlough in the fall of that year. They had expected to return to China, but were not reappointed by the mission board. Rolland practiced medicine in Bellevue, Michigan from 1924 until his death in 1934.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Though the Welches were missionaries in China for a relatively brief time, this collection provides valuable documentation about their missionary experience, the development and operations of a hospital in Hunan Province, and the work of the United Evangelical Mission (later known as the Evangelical Mission). Letters exchanged between Rolland and Lottie during the times of separation when Lottie was in the U.S., Nanking, or at the missionary resort of Kuling provide interesting detail regarding their daily life. Relationships established with both missionary and Chinese colleagues remained influential in the Welches' lives well after their return from China. Their own letters and the letters that the Welches received from missionary colleagues in China after their return to the U.S. in 1923 describe political unrest, banditry, tension within the mission, and the medical work of the mission.

Included in the collection is a set of lantern slides, with descriptions, which were used by Rolland Welch to give presentations about the China mission in churches in the U.S. following their return.

Some documents in the collection are photocopies or scans made from albums that had been compiled by the donor. The original albums were returned to the donor. The photocopies have been integrated into the chronological or alphabetical sequence of the series into which they fit.
